newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices end down 3/8 to 1/2.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices end down 3/8 to 1/2.

text.p: U.S. Municipal bonds closed down 3/8 to 1/2 point after modestly trimming earlier losses incurred when strong November housing starts data hurt U.S. Treasuries.

"I have (muni prices) down like 3/8, I don't think you can say a lot more than that," a trader said. "The market's just absolutely pathetic. There's just so little going on it's hard to figure out what the bids are."
The trader said a fair amount of inventory from recent competitive and negotiated issues remains in dealer hands and the market is "just drifting."
"We bounced off the bottom this morning, but there's just no spin out there, and if you want to get something done it's going to cost you," he said.
The trader said ever since Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan suggested on December 5 that stocks might be overvalued the market has had "a real thin skin."
"So today, when the numbers came out with housing starts, there's not much out there to hold it in," he said.
In the governmnent market, the benchmark 30-year bond pared back earlier losses to end down 15/32 at 97-28/32 to yield 6.66 percent.
In debt futures, the March municipal contract closed down 5/32 at 115-4/32. The March T-bond contract closed down 7/32 at 112-17/32. The MOB spread was 83 ticks.

November housing starts jumped 9.2 percent to a seasonally adjusted rate of 1.514 million units, marking their biggest surge in 16 months and far outpacing expectations. October and September's starts were also revised upward.
A municipal analyst judged the overall muni market down 3/8 to 1/2 point, after having been down 1/2 to 5/8 at one stage.
